You know this film does has its moments. But overall it is a really strange film that comes together too quickly with often ridiculous results. I won't go into detail when regarding the American civil war other than "lolwut?" The actions scenes are actually quite good but the measure of Abraham's strength versus a vampire is unbalanced to say the least. 

It all ends with a somewhat 90s menagerie of explosions and last minute quips. Good for a Sunday afternoon but don't expect any depth in the films story or its characters.

Rate on audio quality, video quality, and movie quality on how the movie was captured!
1- BRRIP- BR stands for Blu-Ray and means the movie was ripped from a Blu-ray disc. It is in 1080p now the p stands for plasma ( the material the sun is made out of. There is 1080ng of plasma in a Blu-ray disc and a 1080p tv) and is called Blu-Ray because everything is blue tinted.
2. DVDRIP- DVD means Digital Video Decoder and this rip is not the movie itself but it is the code, to play this move just press CRTL+R and type the code! Usually in fair-good quality
3. CAMRIP- CAM stands for Complete Audio Movie and this will only be the audio, so please dont be a jerk and type A-10 V-0 because there is no video, duh!
4. TS RIP- TS stands for Television Static and all this means is the picture is fuzzy and when you rate video quality you only rate the picture on how fuzzy it is. ( Ex: V-2 almost completely fuzzy!)
Now please stop rating videos on your own scale !

@Onlyfax

What crack are you somking you stupid peice of shit.

The p in 1080p doesn't stand for plasma you stupid retard. It means progressive scan, as in non interlaced.

BRRIP - means the source was a blu-ray disc. Doesn't mean its in 1080p or anything.

DVDRIP - means the source was from a dvd.

CAMRIP, is a cam recording. As in some guy has recorded the movie being displayed. Like filming at the cinema on your phone.

TS rip is quite similar to camrip.

CAMRIP has both audio and video you twat.

I hope with all my heart that what you wrote was some kind of dumb sarcastic joke.

Anyway. The rip was fine i guess.

Not that I'm not grateful to all the wonderful uploaders who take the time out of their own lives to provide us with free entertainment, but . . . 

What the hell was the point of splitting the video into 2 parts? DVD's are so cheap anymore that I don't see the point of breaking it up to fit on 2 CD's. And even so, it's remarkably easy these days to get the size down to fit on a single CD while maintaining quality, at least if it's a DVD rip (as this one is).

I'm grateful for the free video, I just don't see the point of splitting it. Most of us are probably just playing from a computer anyway.

@DrStoooopid:

You really have absolutely no idea what you're talking about, do you?

There used to be a desirable target size due to optical media constraints and bandwidth limits. Since optical media are slowly going away, why care if the file can fit on a single CDR?

With the cost of large harddrives, who cares about burning anything to a CD or DVD for backup? And with bandwidth that easily reaches 30Mb/s, size is no longer an issue there, either.

So I decided to check your uploads so I could see examples of your video encoding and torrents. Guess what I found? Absolutely nothing.

If you don't like what someone else is providing, do it yourself. If you can't be bothered to do it yourself, shut the fuck up and say thank you to the uploader.

tl;dr: Stop whining like a little bitch about things which are irrelevant in 2012.
